events.summary: Georges Bizet was born as Alexandre César Léopold in Paris, likely causing a whirlwind of confusion at family gatherings. He was baptized as 'Georges' two years later, ensuring that for the rest of his life, people could at least agree on a name.

Bizet didn't just knock on the door of the Conservatoire de Paris; he practically kicked it down at age nine. His musical talent was so stunning that the committee waived the age rule and let him in, proving that sometimes, being precocious pays off.

In a monumental moment of validation, Bizet won the prestigious Prix de Rome at the ripe age of 18. Despite only attending parties and soaking up pasta aromas for a few years, it meant a five-year grant for him to further explore his genius - and probably a lot of Italian cuisine.
Bizet arrived at the Villa Medici in Rome, where he described his new abode as 'paradise,' likely leaving many wondering if he was big on the scenic views or just the gelato.

Bizet attempted his first opera, 'Don Procopio,' while in Rome, breaking the traditional mold by crafting an opera buffa. While he wasn't sure how they felt about that, the Académie didn’t send him packing. Progress, right?

Bizet returned to Paris from his extended Italian getaway, feeling like an explorer returning with tales of culinary conquests and sketches of symphonies as he dove headfirst into an unforgiving opera scene.

Bizet finally premiered his magnum opus, Carmen, which had faced delays for being too spicy for its time. Little did he know, it would go on to become a legendary favorite. Even the heart attack that followed three months later couldn't dim its shine.

events.event: Attended Paris premiere of Wagner's Tannhäuser
events.summary: Bizet braved audience riots and managed to change his mind about Wagner's music from eccentric to brilliant, leading to future ‘Wagnerism’ accusations. Clearly, the riotous atmosphere was instrumental in redefining his taste!

At a dinner party with Liszt, Bizet stole the show by flawlessly playing one of Liszt's notoriously difficult pieces. Liszt was so impressed he claimed there were now three great piano players, one being the 'boldest and most brilliant'—a tall order!

events.event: First performance of Les pêcheurs de perles
events.summary: Bizet's new opera premiered to a lukewarm reception despite Berlioz's praise. It only ran for 18 performances—definitely not the box office hit he hoped for; perhaps audiences were in a seafood mood that evening!

After overcoming family objections contrasting his 'bohemian' ways with their artistic pedigree, Bizet finally tied the knot. Love triumphs, and they mustered up quite the event, despite some impending mother-in-law drama!

events.event: Joined the National Guard during Franco-Prussian War
events.summary: Bizet donned a uniform amidst patriotic fervor, feeling like he was in a historical epic—only to discover his old equipment was more of a hazard to himself than to the enemy. Talk about an 'armed' conflict!
In the midst of chaos, Geneviève gave birth to their only child. This joyous event brought a sprinkle of happiness into their life that was otherwise filled with cannon fire and political upheaval.

Bizet's one-act opera had a rough start with a leading singer missing more music than they sang. Unsurprisingly, it only lasted 11 performances, but at least it gave the audience a brief laugh—even if unintentional!

Bizet was commissioned to compose three acts for the Opéra-Comique, a task he joyfully accepted, excited to adapt Mérimée's scandalous 'Carmen'. Little did he know, this risqué narrative would cause such a stir that even the theatre management felt scandalized!

After the initial excitement of Carmen, Bizet decided to develop Don Rodrigue based on the El Cid story. He playfully played it for baritone Jean-Baptiste Faure, hoping for a rave approval – only for the Opéra to burn down the next day. Talk about bad timing!

Finally, after months of struggles getting Carmen produced, Bizet's opera premiered to a crowd that was half excited and half confused. The performance ran so long that even the night owls were yawning by the final act. Critics were brutal, calling the heroine 'the very incarnation of vice', which probably wasn’t the compliment Bizet dreamed of!

events.event: Chevalier of the Legion of Honour
events.summary: In a moment of delightful irony just before the premiere, Bizet was appointed as a Chevalier of the Legion of Honour. It’s as if the universe wanted to hand him a shiny medal right before everyone started booing his genius!

After battling with throat issues and a variety of ailments that could rival a soap opera storyline, Bizet decided to take a fateful swim and ultimately didn’t make it back. He passed away just when he was becoming known as a 'true artist', giving the phrase 'timing is everything' a whole new layer of meaning.

Bizet's funeral drew an impressive crowd of over 4,000 mourners, which speaks volumes about his popularity posthumously. It was a grand send-off where even Gounod was too emotional to finish his eulogy, proving that the real drama was not just in Bizet's operas but in his life story as well.
Bizet's first opera made its appearance like a toddler taking his first steps—nervously and with mixed reviews, but full of promise!

In a burst of creativity, Bizet composed Carmen, a work that would later confuse audiences but ultimately become a beloved staple of opera repertoire—it's like cuisine that seems strange at first but you can’t stop eating!

Carmen premiered to a lukewarm reception, with audiences scratching their heads in bewilderment, probably thinking, 'Is this opera or a melodrama?' However, history would laugh last as it became a hit.
Bizet's untimely departure from the world left many wondering what other musical gems he could have created—like a painter whose easel suddenly got up and left.
Bizet's first opera 'La maison du docteur' was born, although it was like that creative child who never quite makes it to the school play—unperformed but not forgotten.
With 'Le docteur Miracle,' Bizet finally hit the stage with a performance that made the audience realize this was no miracle; he was simply that good!
Bizet tied the knot with Geneviève Halévy, adding a wonderful duet to his life, even if it meant sharing his desserts.
